p: Third, the centuries-old Westphalian lens of sovereignty cannot deal with emerging GPGs (Nordhaus 2005), and a new type, what Kaul (2013) calls smart power or pooled sovereignty, is warranted. Together, the most fundamental lesson of economics—internalization of emissions externalities—must be applied. So, as Kaul (2017a), a shift away from the lock-in to conventional theorizing of GPGs is warranted, toward a public economics that truly represents the global policy concerns like climate change.
